Age of Demons Finds.name: Age of Demons Finds
Age of Demons Finds.description: Use the Age of Demons Finds table to describe an art object, magic item, or historical curiosity the characters discover on their expeditions into these ancient ruins.

results.1-1: A statuette of a demonic frog-like figure made of an unknown, slimy substance
results.2-2: A dagger with a jagged blade whose handle squirms when held
results.3-3: A jeweled box that screams when opened
results.4-4: A circlet or necklace with prongs that bite into the skin when it’s worn
results.5-5: A plain metal ring that causes its wearer to hear incessant, unintelligible whispers
results.6-6: An amulet or figurine covered with a sickly-looking lichen that feels cold to the touch
results.7-7: A piece of jewelry set with a translucent gemstone; an indistinct shape inside the gem moves at random
results.8-8: A weapon made from dark metal that dims the light immediately surrounding it
results.9-9: A die made of petrified bone with mysterious glyphs on the faces
results.10-10: Glass bangles of shifting colors that make no sound striking against each other
results.11-11: A metal scepter topped with a monstrous head much denser than the rest of the scepter, which makes it unbalanced
results.12-12: A medallion or sculpture depicting a Fiend locked in battle with a Celestial or Dragon

Airborne Encounters.description: You may use the following table to generate random encounters as adventurers navigate the skies.

results.1-1: A gleaming Lyrandar Air Cruiser helmed by a Friendly but pompous @UUID[Compendium.dnd-monster-manual.actors.Actor.mmNobleProdigy00]{Noble Prodigy} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd-forge-artificer.actors.Actor.efaLyrandarScion]{Lyrandar Scion} (described in chapter 5)
results.2-2: A Strider Airship with a Hostile crew of [[/gmr 2d4]] @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.actors24.Actor.mmPirate00000000]{Pirates} and one @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.actors24.Actor.mmPirateCaptain0]{Pirate Captain}
results.3-3: [[/gmr 2d6]] @UUID[Compendium.dnd-forge-artificer.actors.Actor.efaLysanderSkysk]{Lyrandar Skyskiffs} gathered for a race; the ships’ pilots are Indifferent but disgruntled toward anyone who interrupts their activities
results.4-4: A derelict @UUID[Compendium.dnd-forge-artificer.actors.Actor.efaLyranderAirCr]{Lyrandar Air Cruiser}, stranded in the sky after its engine’s elemental core shattered
results.7-7: Two @UUID[Compendium.dnd-monster-manual.actors.Actor.mmSphinxOfSecret]{Sphinxes of Secrets}, trying to figure out how the airship flies
results.9-9: A flock of [[/gmr 2d4]] @UUID[Compendium.dnd-monster-manual.actors.Actor.mmPeryton0000000]{Perytons} hiding in a cloud, waiting to ambush unsuspecting travelers
results.10-10: One @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.actors24.Actor.mmRoc00000000000]{Roc} looking for food to carry to its nest

Environmental Hazards.name: Environmental Hazards
Environmental Hazards.description: With no terrain obstacles to worry about, the most significant obstacles in airship travel are environmental effects caused by weather. The Environmental Hazards table suggests obstacles an airship might have to overcome.

results.1-1: The airship experiences rough turbulence. Each creature aboard the ship must succeed on a [[/save con dc=10 format=long]] or have the &Reference[Poisoned] condition for [[/gmr 1d4]] hours due to motion sickness.
results.2-2: The airship travels at extreme altitudes for [[/gmr 1d4]] hours. During this time, the ship is in an area of extreme cold (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgDmsToolbox000.JournalEntryPage.xgLA30rErlkjIPAK]{“Environmental Effects”} in the Dungeon Master’s Guide) and reduced gravity: creatures’ and objects’ weights are halved, and creatures’ High Jump and Long Jump distances are doubled.
results.3-3: The airship passes through a lightning storm, which takes [[/gmr 1d4]] hours. During this time, the area around the ship is &Reference[Heavily Obscured], and any creature that starts its turn on the ship’s deck must succeed on a [[/save dex dc=10 format=long]] or be struck by lightning and take [[/damage 1d8 type=lightning average]].
results.4-4: The airship enters an area of strong wind (see @UUID[Compendium.dnd-dungeon-masters-guide.content.JournalEntry.dmgDmsToolbox000.JournalEntryPage.xgLA30rErlkjIPAK]{“Environmental Effects”} in the Dungeon Master’s Guide), which lasts for [[/gmr 1d4]] hours. When the ship first enters this area, the crew member operating the ship’s Helm must succeed on a [[/save con dc=15 format=long]], or the ship inverts.

Experimental Elixir.name: Experimental Elixir
Experimental Elixir.description: Whenever you finish a Long Rest while holding Alchemist’s Supplies, you can use that tool to magically produce two elixirs. For each elixir, roll on the Experimental Elixir table for the elixir’s effect, which is triggered when someone drinks the elixir. The elixir appears in a vial, and the vial vanishes when the elixir is drunk or poured out. If any elixir remains when you finish a Long Rest, the elixir and its vial vanish.

results.6-6:

House Intrigue.name: House Intrigue
House Intrigue.description: Eberron: Rising from the Last War includes suggestions for building adventures focused on individual dragonmarked houses, but the most interesting adventures involve interaction between multiple houses. Use the House Intrigue table to inspire plots involving two or more houses.

results.1-1: Dragonmarked houses vie for influence over a prominent individual (perhaps one of the characters).
results.2-2: Dragonmarked houses compete for control of a key site.
results.3-3: Tension builds between two rival dragonmarked houses, threatening to erupt into a deadly feud.
results.4-4: Villains from two or more dragonmarked houses form a dangerous alliance.
results.5-5: A villain tries to disrupt an alliance between two or more dragonmarked houses.
results.6-6: Splinter factions from two dragonmarked houses try to form a new house.

Jungle Mishaps.description: On a failed check, the party gets off course, makes no progress that day, and encounters a group of Hostile drow; roll on the Jungle Mishaps table to determine the encounter.

Party Makeup.name: Party Makeup
Party Makeup.description: You can assemble a diverse party of D&D characters drawn from a single dragonmarked house. Conversely, your party can include members of different houses united by alliances or common principles. Or they could be childhood friends who ended up working for different houses, or just a haphazard collection of individuals thrown together by unforeseen circumstances. The Party Makeup table suggests ways to justify why the characters are cooperating.

results.1-1: One-House Party. Choose a dragonmarked house and connect all characters to it.
results.2-2: Bodyguards. A Deneith Fighter, a Jorasco Cleric, a Medani Wizard, and a Phiarlan Monk are assigned to protect important people.
results.3-3: Bounty Hunters. A Sivis Bard, a Tharashk Barbarian, a Tharashk Ranger, and a Vadalis Druid venture into the wild to pursue fugitives.
results.4-4: Dragonshard Prospectors. House Tharashk leads a dragonshard-mining expedition, sending a Druid and a Ranger accompanied by a Lyrandar Sorcerer and a Thuranni Bard.
results.5-5: Lawkeepers. A Deneith Fighter, a Deneith Paladin, a Lyrandar Sorcerer, and a Medani Rogue enforce the law—particularly the terms of the Treaty of Thronehold, which governs international law.
results.6-6: Medical Extraction Team. A Cannith Artificer, a Deneith Paladin, a Jorasco Cleric, and a Thuranni Monk venture into war zones and disaster areas to protect civilians, heal them, and escort them away from danger.
results.7-7: Researchers. A Cannith Artificer, a Deneith Paladin, a Medani Rogue (Arcane Trickster), and a Sivis Wizard carry out arcane research for the Twelve.
results.8-8: Strike Force. A Cannith Artificer, a Deneith Fighter, a Jorasco Cleric, and a Thuranni Rogue strike hard and fast against enemies of the dragonmarked houses or the Five Nations as a whole.
